title: Isaiah Chapter 60 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 60 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 60 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 60.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:1, what has risen upon thee?
questions.correctAnswer: The glory of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:1 states that the glory of the LORD is risen upon thee.

questions.question: What shall cover the earth according to Isaiah 60:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:2 says that darkness shall cover the earth, and gross darkness the people.

questions.question: Who shall come to thy light according to Isaiah 60:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:3 states that the Gentiles shall come to thy light.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 60:4 mentions that thy daughters shall be nursed at thy side.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:4 clearly states that thy daughters shall be nursed at thy side.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:6, what shall the multitude of camels bring?
questions.correctAnswer: Gold and incense
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:6 says they shall bring gold and incense.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 60:7: 'All the flocks of _____ shall be gathered together unto thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: Kedar
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:7 states that all the flocks of Kedar shall be gathered together unto thee.

questions.question: Who are described as flying as a cloud and as doves to their windows in Isaiah 60:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Those coming to thee
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:8 questions 'Who are these that fly as a cloud, and as the doves to their windows?' referring to those coming to thee.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 60:11 states that thy gates shall be shut day and night.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:11 states that thy gates shall be open continually; they shall not be shut day nor night.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:12, what will happen to the nation and kingdom that will not serve thee?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:12 says that the nation and kingdom that will not serve thee shall perish.

questions.question: What shall be brought to beautify the place of my sanctuary according to Isaiah 60:13?
options: The glory of Lebanon, the fir tree, the pine tree, and the box
questions.correctAnswer: The glory of Lebanon, the fir tree, the pine tree, and the box
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:13 mentions the glory of Lebanon, the fir tree, the pine tree, and the box to beautify the place of my sanctuary.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 60:14 says that all who despiseth thee shall bow themselves down at the soles of thy feet.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:14 states that all they that despised thee shall bow themselves down at the soles of thy feet.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:15, what will the LORD make thee?
options: An eternal excellency, a joy of many generations
questions.correctAnswer: An eternal excellency, a joy of many generations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:15 says the LORD will make thee an eternal excellency, a joy of many generations.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 60:16: 'Thou shalt also suck the milk of the Gentiles, and shalt suck the breast of _____.'
questions.correctAnswer: kings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:16 states 'Thou shalt also suck the milk of the Gentiles, and shalt suck the breast of kings.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:18, what shall no more be heard in thy land?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:18 states that violence shall no more be heard in thy land.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:19, what shall be unto thee an everlasting light?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:19 says the LORD shall be unto thee an everlasting light.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 60 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 60 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear and feels small in their service to God. Based on Isaiah 60, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: Arise and shine, for the glory of the LORD is risen upon you
You must work harder to earn God's favor
God only blesses the strong and mighty
You are alone in your struggles
questions.correctAnswer: Arise and shine, for the glory of the LORD is risen upon you
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:1 encourages believers to arise and shine because the glory of the LORD is upon them. This shows that God’s presence brings confidence and strength, helping overcome fear and smallness (Isaiah 60:1, 2, 5).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 60 teach us about the importance of trusting God's timing in the growth of His kingdom?
options: A little one shall become a thousand, and I will hasten it in my time
You must force God's plan through your own efforts
Growth depends solely on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: A little one shall become a thousand, and I will hasten it in my time
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:22 teaches that God controls the growth of His kingdom, and He will hasten it according to His timing. Believers should trust God's sovereign plan rather than relying on their own timing or strength (Isaiah 60:22, 3, 12).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 60 say about the role of Gentiles and kings in God's plan, and how does this encourage us in evangelism?
options: Gentiles and kings shall come to your light and brightness
Only the Jewish people are included in God's plan
Kings will oppose God's people forever
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles and kings shall come to your light and brightness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:3 states that Gentiles and kings will be drawn to God's light, highlighting the inclusive nature of God's salvation. This encourages believers to evangelize knowing God's plan includes all nations (Isaiah 60:3, 6, 9).

questions.question: A believer feels isolated and forgotten. According to Isaiah 60, what hope can you share about God's future blessings?
options: You will be an eternal excellency and a joy to many generations
You will remain forsaken and alone
God will leave you to fend for yourself
You must earn your way back by works
questions.correctAnswer: You will be an eternal excellency and a joy to many generations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:15 promises restoration and lasting honor to those once forsaken, assuring believers that God will bless them abundantly and bring joy through many generations (Isaiah 60:15, 14, 21).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 60 encourage believers to approach personal and communal holiness in light of God's glory?
options: Lift up your eyes and see the gathering of your sons and daughters
Ignore God's glory and focus on worldly matters
Trust only in your own righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up your eyes and see the gathering of your sons and daughters
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:4 calls believers to recognize God's work in gathering His people, encouraging faith, community, and holiness as a reflection of God's glory (Isaiah 60:4, 21, 7).

questions.question: What principle about generosity and stewardship can be drawn from the image of camels bringing gold and incense in Isaiah 60?
options: Generosity honors God and reflects His praises
We should withhold resources to protect ourselves
Material wealth is unrelated to faith
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity honors God and reflects His praises
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:6 describes camels bringing gold and incense to praise the LORD, illustrating that generous giving honors God and expresses worship (Isaiah 60:6, 7, 9).

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 60, violence and destruction will continue within God's restored people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:18 promises that violence and destruction will no longer be heard or seen within God's borders, indicating a future of peace and safety for His people (Isaiah 60:18, 17, 19).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 60 instruct believers to respond to past afflictions and despising by others?
options: Those who afflicted and despised you will bow and call you the city of the LORD
Seek revenge on those who hurt you
questions.correctAnswer: Those who afflicted and despised you will bow and call you the city of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:14 teaches that former enemies will recognize God's blessing on His people and show humility, encouraging believers to trust God's justice and restoration rather than personal retaliation (Isaiah 60:14, 15).

questions.question: In the context of Isaiah 60, what does the continual opening of gates symbolize for believers in their walk with God?
options: Constant access and openness to God's blessings and fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: Constant access and openness to God's blessings and fellowship
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:11 speaks of gates remaining open day and night, symbolizing continual access to God's blessings and fellowship, encouraging believers to live in openness and welcome others (Isaiah 60:11, 9).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on their own strength for righteousness. How does Isaiah 60 correct this mindset?
options: God will make your officers peace and your exactors righteousness
You must achieve righteousness on your own
Only rituals can make you right with God
questions.correctAnswer: God will make your officers peace and your exactors righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:17 promises God’s transformation of roles and righteousness, indicating that true righteousness comes from God’s work, not human effort alone (Isaiah 60:17, 21).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 60 teaches that God's light will replace the sun and moon as the source of illumination for His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:19-20 explains that the LORD Himself will be the everlasting light, replacing the sun and moon, symbolizing God's eternal guidance and presence (Isaiah 60:19-20).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 60 illustrate the role of humility and submission in relationship to God’s blessings?
options: Those who afflicted and despised you shall bow at your feet
You must assert dominance over others to receive blessings
Ignore God's ways and rely on your own
questions.correctAnswer: Those who afflicted and despised you shall bow at your feet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:14 shows that humility and submission by others in respect to God’s people reflect the honor God bestows, teaching believers to embrace humility as part of God's blessings (Isaiah 60:14, 15).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their family is far from faith. What hope does Isaiah 60 offer about family restoration?
options: Your sons shall come from far, and your daughters shall be nursed at your side
Family has no role in faith
God only cares about individuals, not families
questions.correctAnswer: Your sons shall come from far, and your daughters shall be nursed at your side
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:4 promises restoration and gathering of family members, encouraging believers to trust God for family reconciliation and spiritual blessing (Isaiah 60:4, 9).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 60 teaches that the sun shall be no more thy light by day; neither for brightness shall the moon give light unto thee: but the LORD shall be unto thee an ________ light.
questions.correctAnswer: everlasting
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:19 clearly states that the LORD will be an everlasting light to His people, symbolizing permanent divine guidance and glory.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 60 teach about dealing with trials and affliction in the context of God's favor?
options: Though smitten in wrath, God shows mercy and favor afterward
Trials mean God has abandoned you permanently
Affliction is a sign of God's rejection forever
You must suffer alone without hope
questions.correctAnswer: Though smitten in wrath, God shows mercy and favor afterward
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:10 explains that despite past punishment, God’s favor and mercy will restore His people, encouraging perseverance and trust during trials (Isaiah 60:10, 15).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 60 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 60.

questions.question: What is the significance of the command 'Arise, shine' in Isaiah 60:1 in relation to the theme of restoration in the Hebrew Bible?
options: It symbolizes the return of Israel’s glory after exile
It refers to the creation of the world
It commands the building of a new temple
It predicts a future war against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the return of Israel’s glory after exile
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:1 calls Israel to 'Arise, shine' because 'thy light is come,' symbolizing restoration and divine favor after a period of darkness and exile, a theme consistent with prophetic literature about Israel’s return.

questions.question: In Isaiah 60:3, which groups are described as coming to the 'light' and 'brightness' of Israel, and what is their symbolic meaning?
options: Gentiles and kings, symbolizing the inclusion of the nations
Prophets and priests, symbolizing religious leadership
Angels and heavenly hosts, symbolizing divine presence
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles and kings, symbolizing the inclusion of the nations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:3 speaks of Gentiles and kings coming to Israel’s light, symbolizing the universal scope of God's salvation extending beyond Israel to the nations, a foreshadowing of the Messianic kingdom.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Isaiah 60:5 with the phrase 'thine heart shall fear, and be enlarged'?
questions.correctAnswer: Antithesis
questions.explanation: The phrase contrasts 'fear' with 'be enlarged,' showing antithesis to express a complex emotional response to the abundance coming to Israel, reflecting both awe and joy.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:6, what do the camels from Midian, Ephah, and Sheba bring, and how does this reflect ancient Near Eastern trade practices?
options: Gold and incense, representing luxury goods and tribute
Silver and spices, symbolizing wealth and healing
Weapons and armor, indicating military support
questions.correctAnswer: Gold and incense, representing luxury goods and tribute
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:6 mentions gold and incense brought by camels from these regions, reflecting historical trade routes where such valuable goods were exchanged as tribute or gifts.

questions.question: In Isaiah 60:7, what is the significance of the rams of Nebaioth ministering and coming up with acceptance on the altar?
options: It symbolizes the inclusion of foreign worshippers into Israel’s religious life
It predicts a sacrificial war against Israel’s enemies
It describes a physical migration of flocks
It refers to a festival specific to the tribe of Nebaioth
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the inclusion of foreign worshippers into Israel’s religious life
questions.explanation: The rams of Nebaioth ministering on the altar indicate acceptance of foreign peoples’ offerings, symbolizing a future inclusive worship and universal acknowledgement of God.

questions.question: The imagery of 'flying as a cloud, and as doves to their windows' in Isaiah 60:8 is an example of what literary technique?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:8 uses similes comparing people to clouds and doves approaching their windows, emphasizing their swift and peaceful arrival.

questions.question: How does the mention of 'the ships of Tarshish' in Isaiah 60:9 connect to Israel’s historical and economic context?
options: It indicates long-distance trade and wealth from maritime commerce
It refers to a naval battle predicted by the prophet
It symbolizes the destruction of Israel’s enemies
It represents a pilgrimage route to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates long-distance trade and wealth from maritime commerce
questions.explanation: Tarshish was known for maritime trade; the ships bringing silver and gold symbolize economic prosperity and international connections in Isaiah 60:9.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 60:10 describes a reversal of fortune where former enemies and strangers will build up Jerusalem's walls and serve its kings.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:10 explicitly states that sons of strangers will build the walls and their kings will minister to Jerusalem, indicating a restoration and reversal of former hostility.

questions.question: What theological message is conveyed through the statement in Isaiah 60:12 that nations not serving Israel will perish?
options: God’s sovereign judgment and the establishment of Israel’s supremacy
A call for Israel to conquer all nations militarily
A prophecy of natural disasters affecting neighboring countries
An allegorical reference to spiritual warfare
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign judgment and the establishment of Israel’s supremacy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:12 emphasizes that nations rejecting Israel’s God will be destroyed, highlighting divine sovereignty and the ultimate triumph of God’s kingdom.

questions.question: In Isaiah 60:13, the 'glory of Lebanon' including fir, pine, and box trees is used to symbolize what?
options: The beautification and sanctification of God's sanctuary
The establishment of Israelite forestry laws
questions.correctAnswer: The beautification and sanctification of God's sanctuary
questions.explanation: The precious trees from Lebanon in Isaiah 60:13 symbolize the adornment and glory of the sanctuary, emphasizing God's presence and holiness.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:14, who will come 'bending' and bow at the city called 'The city of the LORD' and what does this indicate?
options: Those who afflicted and despised Israel, indicating repentance and submission
The priests and Levites, indicating religious reform
questions.correctAnswer: Those who afflicted and despised Israel, indicating repentance and submission
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:14 shows former enemies humbling themselves before Jerusalem, signifying a reversal of fortunes and recognition of God's holiness.

questions.question: The phrase 'Thou shalt also suck the milk of the Gentiles, and shalt suck the breast of kings' in Isaiah 60:16 is an example of what type of biblical imagery?
options: Metaphor for receiving nourishment and benefits from foreign powers
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor for receiving nourishment and benefits from foreign powers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:16 uses maternal imagery metaphorically to express Israel’s receiving blessings and support from Gentile nations and rulers.

questions.question: How does the transformation described in Isaiah 60:17 (brass to gold, iron to silver) function as a typology in biblical literature?
options: It symbolizes spiritual renewal and divine upgrade of Israel’s status
It illustrates the economic exchange rates
It refers to the building materials for the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes spiritual renewal and divine upgrade of Israel’s status
questions.explanation: The exchange of common metals for precious ones in Isaiah 60:17 typifies God’s transformative work in elevating Israel spiritually and materially.

questions.question: What is the significance of the statement in Isaiah 60:18 that 'Violence shall no more be heard in thy land' in the context of ancient Near Eastern history?
options: It promises peace and stability after prolonged conflict and exile
It predicts the end of all wars globally
It calls for the disarmament of Israel
It refers to a temporary ceasefire
questions.correctAnswer: It promises peace and stability after prolonged conflict and exile
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:18 contrasts past violence with a future era of peace, reflecting hope for security after periods of turmoil common in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 60:19-20 indicates that natural sources of light like the sun and moon will be replaced by the LORD as an everlasting light, foreshadowing New Testament themes of Christ as the light of the world.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:19-20 describes the LORD as an everlasting light replacing sun and moon, a motif echoed in John 8:12 where Jesus declares Himself the light of the world.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 60 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 60 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:1, what event prompts the command to 'Arise, shine'?
options: Thy light is come, and the glory of the LORD is risen upon thee
The darkness shall cover the earth
The Gentiles shall come to thy light
The gates shall be open continually
questions.correctAnswer: Thy light is come, and the glory of the LORD is risen upon thee
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:1 commands to arise and shine because 'thy light is come, and the glory of the LORD is risen upon thee.' This reflects the manifestation of God's glory, echoed in John 1:4-5 where Christ is the light shining in darkness, and Revelation 21:23 where God's glory illuminates the New Jerusalem.

questions.question: In Isaiah 60:2, what is contrasted with the glory of the LORD rising upon the people?
options: Darkness covering the earth and gross darkness the people
The abundance of the sea being converted
The sons of strangers building walls
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness covering the earth and gross darkness the people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:2 contrasts the darkness covering the earth and gross darkness the people with the LORD arising upon His people and His glory being seen. This theme of light overcoming darkness aligns with John 1:5 and 2 Corinthians 4:6, highlighting divine salvation overcoming sin and ignorance.

questions.question: Who are said to come to the light and brightness in Isaiah 60:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles and kings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:3 states that 'the Gentiles shall come to thy light, and kings to the brightness of thy rising,' indicating the universal scope of God's salvation. This is consistent with Acts 13:47 and Revelation 21:24 where Gentiles and kings are drawn into God's kingdom.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:6, what do those coming from Sheba bring?
questions.correctAnswer: Gold and incense
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:6 describes those from Sheba bringing gold and incense, symbolizing honor and worship. This foreshadows the gifts brought by the Magi to Jesus (Matthew 2:11) and reflects Psalm 45:8 where incense symbolizes prayer and worship.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 60:7 say will be glorified as a result of the offerings brought to the altar?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of my glory
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:7 speaks of offerings brought up with acceptance on God's altar, leading Him to glorify 'the house of my glory.' This reflects God's dwelling among His people (Exodus 29:43) and is fulfilled in Christ as the true temple (John 2:19-21).

questions.question: Isaiah 60:9 mentions the ships of Tarshish bringing what to the name of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver and gold
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:9 describes the ships of Tarshish bringing silver and gold to honor the LORD. This symbolizes the wealth and tribute paid to God by the nations, consistent with Psalm 72:10 and Revelation 21:24 where kings bring gifts to God.

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah 60:10 give for the sons of strangers building up the walls and kings ministering?
options: Because in God's wrath He smote, but in His favor He had mercy
Because the city was forsaken and hated
Because the gates shall be open continually
Because the sun shall no more go down
questions.correctAnswer: Because in God's wrath He smote, but in His favor He had mercy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:10 explains that the restoration, including foreigners building walls and kings ministering, is due to God's mercy after judgment. This reflects the theme of divine discipline and restoration found in Hebrews 12:6 and Lamentations 3:31-33.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 60:11, what is unique about the gates of the city?
options: They shall be open continually, not shut day nor night
They shall be made of gold and silver
They shall be guarded by angels
They shall be built by the sons of strangers
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be open continually, not shut day nor night
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:11 states the gates shall never be shut, symbolizing perpetual access and welcome to the forces of Gentiles and their kings. This is echoed in Revelation 21:25 where the gates of the New Jerusalem are always open.

questions.question: What will happen to the nation and kingdom that will not serve the city, according to Isaiah 60:12?
options: They shall perish and be utterly wasted
They shall be incorporated into the city
They shall be given peace and righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish and be utterly wasted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:12 declares that nations refusing to serve God's city will perish, reflecting God's judgment. This aligns with Romans 13:1-4 on God's sovereign judgment and Revelation 20:9 where rebellious nations face destruction.

questions.question: Which trees are mentioned in Isaiah 60:13 as coming to beautify the sanctuary?
options: Fir tree, pine tree, and box
questions.correctAnswer: Fir tree, pine tree, and box
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:13 lists fir, pine, and box trees to beautify the sanctuary, symbolizing renewal and divine glory. This imagery corresponds with Psalm 92:12-13 and Ezekiel 17:22-24 illustrating flourishing under God's care.

questions.question: Isaiah 60:14 prophesies that those who once afflicted and despised the city will do what?
options: Come bending and bow down at the soles of thy feet
Continue to reject and fight against it
questions.correctAnswer: Come bending and bow down at the soles of thy feet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:14 predicts former enemies will humbly submit, calling it 'The city of the LORD.' This theme of repentance and homage is also found in Philippians 2:10-11 and Revelation 7:9-10.

questions.question: What transformation of the city is described in Isaiah 60:15?
options: From forsaken and hated to an eternal excellency, a joy of many generations
From a place of violence to a land of peace
From a shadow to a great light
From a small nation to a strong kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: From forsaken and hated to an eternal excellency, a joy of many generations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:15 declares the city's restoration from abandonment to eternal glory and joy, echoing God's promises in Jeremiah 31:12 and Revelation 21:4 of everlasting restoration and blessing.

questions.question: In Isaiah 60:16, what metaphor is used to describe the relationship between the city and the Gentiles and kings?
options: Thou shalt suck the milk of the Gentiles, and shalt suck the breast of kings
They shall be as a shield and buckler
They shall be as a vine and branches
They shall be as stones in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt suck the milk of the Gentiles, and shalt suck the breast of kings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:16 uses the metaphor of nursing to describe the city's receiving sustenance and wealth from Gentiles and kings, emphasizing divine provision and blessing. This is consistent with Psalm 81:16 and Galatians 4:4-7 on God's provision through nations.

questions.question: Isaiah 60:17 speaks of exchanging common materials for precious ones. What is the correct exchange?
options: For brass I will bring gold, and for iron I will bring silver
For wood I will bring brass, and for stones iron
For silver I will bring gold, and for iron I will bring brass
For gold I will bring silver, and for brass I will bring iron
questions.correctAnswer: For brass I will bring gold, and for iron I will bring silver
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:17 describes God's transformative provision, replacing common metals with precious ones, symbolizing spiritual exaltation and blessing. This theme of divine enrichment is reflected in 2 Corinthians 3:18 and Revelation 21:18-21.

questions.question: What will no longer be heard in the land according to Isaiah 60:18?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence, wasting, nor destruction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 60:18 promises that violence, wasting, and destruction will cease within the land, signifying peace and divine protection. This is consistent with Isaiah 2:4 and Revelation 21:4 where God's kingdom brings peace and ends suffering.
